caption: Lovely library that open on Monday when mamy other library closes. It was nice building with many old books and the stair is charming. I just enter the reading room, I wish there were more table. The coffee machine nearby with only 0.45‚Ç¨. Couldn't ask for more. It locates in a nice neighborhood.

We were so surprised to get in that library!! It was so big and bad all these very old books and manuscripts that you can actually rent. They also had huge maps of Paris throughout history. Really a great and unique library. If you are in the neighbourhood, I for sure recommend to visit it : it does not take too much time and is beautiful!

üìö The Biblioth√®que Historique de la Ville de Paris is a public library specializing in the history of the city of Paris and the √éle-de-France region. It is located in the H√¥tel d‚ÄôAngoul√™me Lamoignon, a historic building from the 16th century in the Marais district.  üëç I loved visiting this library, which has impressive collections of books, manuscripts, maps, photographs, drawings, prints, posters and postcards on various topics related to Paris, such as theater, literature and feminism. The staff is very friendly and professional, and the atmosphere is calm and cozy.  üåü I give 5 stars to this library, which is a treasure for lovers of history and Parisian culture. I recommend it without a doubt to anyone who wants to know more about this fascinating city.

Beautiful place. I love it. Is the most kind library that I know in Paris. They offer to you free coffee, tea, water, and biscuits. Additionally, is really quite place, perfect for study. Just a little bit boring to leave your stuff in a locker (why?)

Having lived in Paris over 6 years now, I can say that this beautiful library/study room is my favorite place to go when I have free time. If you like history- especially Paris history, you will appreciate the book collection of all things of historical significance that have happened in Paris since the last 2,000 years or so. If you want to work in the study room, you need to get a special library card. It's easy to do and free, but you need an identity photo and proof of address. Otherwise, you can still come and hangout in the public space which has books, magazines, maps, computers, and expositions. And the best part?? The 50 cent coffee machine!!
Went here nearly every day for a quiet, atmospheric place to write
I do not recommend at all to visit this place as you cannot have the access to the main library even just for one day and not even visit it. People are quite rude and made me feel discriminated.
Beautiful place to visit. You can spend some time in the library to study, have some tea. And take the time to take a look at the building.

Quite nice for studying. Beautiful interior, silent atmosphere. Surrounded by attractive place so that you can easily change your mood when you stuck with your work by roam around here. Caffeinated drinks available only 0.5‚Ç¨ at corner of this library.

I come here to study/do homework on my laptop. The public wifi from Paris has perfect signal inside the reading area. The tables have assigned numbers  so you get a little square of space to work on. I recommend bringing a thin foldable bag to carry your things inside the room because you can‚Äôt bring in your laptop case or backpack, (or water bottle, sadly), so it would be messy if you carry what you need just with your arms. The chairs are comfortable enough. There are power sockets on the tables and lamps. Overall pretty good if you need to focus ;) UPDATE: no one had told me anything for bringing my own little fabric bag with my belongings, but beware of this really rude lady that might yell at you for this. Then they give you a noisy plastic bag that who knows how many people has touched and that I‚Äôm sure is not disinfected.
Beautifully restored building . The main foyer is worth visiting just to look at the old maps of the city. There is also an excellent reading room which needs an ID card to gain entry.
It‚Äôs very loud if you aren‚Äôt a resident (and don‚Äôt have a card) and can‚Äôt  go into your the large room to work. Otherwise, a nice space to read.
For the dedicated old books lover
Wonderful library but the internet speed makes it hard to be productive.
Lovely library and their librarians/personnel is just the kindest.
Wonderful place
Great place!
Cool
Great place

A library installed in a magnificent place where the atmosphere is studious. Each workstation has an electrical outlet and a lamp. The chairs are very comfortable. In summer, there are tables for lunch in the courtyard. There are regular exhibitions which brighten up the place. We often work with classical music coming through the open windows of the nearby Hotel Carnavalet.  If we want to find some negative points: - too bad the coffee machine has been under repair for so long (almost two months) - nothing to dry your hands in the toilet (the hand dryers work very poorly)

The library itself deserves more than 3 stars but the reading room is by far the noisiest I have been in (and I have visited libraries) Many visitors speak very loudly while walking around but also from personal: for example today A strong, graying-haired gentleman who works on site came to replace certain newspapers and magazines, throwing them away and shouting at a visitor who wanted to help himself "are you waiting" without any polite expression, others ladies on staff who speak super loudly while there are several of us reading and in no way invite people to speak less loudly.  Very unfortunate for a place where calm, tranquility and respect for others must prevail.

Open day this Sunday September 17, 2023 an interesting visit on the discovery of Paris described based on 2 old and huge maps of the city. Old photos from different Tours de France are visible. The interior courtyard is superb with sculptures of Diana the Huntress. The guides told us about Diane D'angoul√™me and her nephew Charles who participated in the construction of the 16th century building.  It was transformed into this library and was transferred and therefore now belongs to the city of Paris since 1960. Thanks to the various guides!
Very nice library both for working in peace and for reading the press. Garden at the back.
A place steeped in history, this magnificent 15th-18th century mansion in the heart of the Marais. Pleasant library with decorated ceiling. The main courtyard is grandiose.

The place is magnificent and the people at reception very friendly but I was verbally attacked by the person "in charge of monitoring the room" (that's how she introduced herself) because I had a computer bag. The same message could have been communicated more politely. I would point out that I had shown my bag at reception before entering. This person stayed in the lobby to make sure I left the room. Truly pitiful. It was my first visit.
Very beautiful place, very quiet. And very friendly staff, very attentive. Really great experience, I'm coming back in March.üòâ ‚Ä¶

I came across this library by chance and was very pleasantly surprised by the fact that the library has historical books about Paris dating from the seventeenth century to the present day displayed in the hall. Visitors are welcome to browse and even rent the books. Normally, seventeenth-century books are always stored in archives and you have to request them specifically, so it is very special that they are so open and exposed here. Very happy to see that this kind of heritage is actively made available to a wide audience!

Excellent municipal library, located in a magnificent and very old private mansion in the Marais, the H√¥tel de Lamavoine, built in the 16th century by Philibert Delorme. Very nice reading room. In addition, on the ground floor you can consult a very large set of plans of Paris from different periods, in their original editions, and in particular the plates of Turgot's plan from 1734-39, in cavalier perspective.
The place is very beautiful but to have access to the main working room you have the library card and to have this card you have to be an adult so I did not have access to the outlet

The library‚Ä¶it is a place of culture that should be accessible to everyone. Without any type of discrimination, that's not the case, they will do everything to find excuses to prevent you from being granted access... typically French (they love to say "no! So that‚Äôs what I advise you to do, is to say that you are going to use it regularly, they will give you a pass to access it!

A very classic and beautiful little library. There are not many seats and you need to change your card (Paris Special Library card), but it is quite quiet. A little seriousness is a minor drawback. It had just been renovated a while ago, so I took a photo, but it was a pity that I didn‚Äôt take the photo in the reading hall~

Magnificent place! Registration is quick and free, and the room is wonderful. On the other hand, the space reserved for those who have not registered should be avoided absolutely!  As in any library in Ile de France, it tolerates the homeless. Nothing wrong with the principle but, in this case, the smallness of the place poses major odor problems. However, as registration is free, you just need to be quick enough to find a place in the room

I went to the library last week, and understand the legitimacy of paying special attention to theft, but don't understand the point of emptying my bag and putting it completely empty in a locker? (and put my stuff in a plastic bag?). I needed all of my books and happily offered to have my bag and personal belongings checked without the slightest resistance on my way out of the reading room. There were 2 people at reception, might as well put one person in the reading room? Please do not see this as malicious criticism, and thank you in advance for taking this possibility into consideration in order to allow everyone to benefit from this workspace.

beautiful library. I go there often because I can concentrate. Bringing personal items into the reading room is restricted, and you must enter the lockers with the same number as your assigned table after the room is closed.
Arrests from 1750. Haussmann recounting his work,...

Nice place. It's small but pretty. The staff is friendly. It has a space reserved for eating and talking, you can have coffee for less than one euro. There is internet and places to charge devices available.
A very nice place to study, a nice library

Very beautiful library with maps of ancient Paris. Very interesting and fun to compare with current Paris.  The decoration is magnificent. There is an "exhibition" section with some works, old books that weigh their weight. A small cafeteria is available.  A second part which is a workplace on presentation of the identity card and you must present yourself at reception.
